content.raw: The problem seems to be sensitive to the amount of sleep time in ConnectionManager.cc:265. I increased the sleep time from 1 ms back to 30 ms, and I was able to make it farther into the factory_stress test. Likewise, if I reduce the sleep to 10 us, it hangs much more quickly.
content.html: The problem seems to be sensitive to the amount of sleep time in ConnectionManager.cc:265. I increased the sleep time from 1 ms back to 30 ms, and I was able to make it farther into the factory_stress test. Likewise, if I reduce the sleep to 10 us, it hangs much more quickly.

content.raw:
I've run a jenkins DRI powered run in our real-vrc machine in Amazon: http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-vrc/5/

Four tests are failing there:

* **physics**: for Timeout. we should probably work on split this test into proper smaller cases.
* **contact_sensor**: ContactSensor.StackTestODE

```
#!

91: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-vrc/gazebo/test/ServerFixture.hh:683: Failure
91: Expected: (i) < (50), actual: 50 vs 50
91: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-vrc/gazebo/test/regression/contact_sensor.cc:234: Failure
91: Value of: fabs(actualTorque.x) < odeTorqueTol
91:   Actual: false
91: Expected: true
91: [  FAILED  ] ContactSensor.StackTestODE (6743 ms)

```
*  **Imu**: ImuTest.EmptyWorldNoiseODE
```
97: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-vrc/gazebo/test/ServerFixture.hh:623: Failure
97: Expected: (i) < (50), actual: 50 vs 50
97: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-vrc/gazebo/test/regression/imu.cc:148: Failure
97: Value of: imu
97:   Actual: false
97: Expected: true
97: [1;31mError [SensorManager.cc:340][0m Unable to remove sensor[default::imu_model::body::imu_sensor] because it does not exist.
97: [  FAILED  ] ImuTest.EmptyWorldNoiseODE (7331 ms)
``` 
* **transport_test: ** this is probably for the difference in machine performance
```
09: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-vrc/gazebo/test/regression/transport_stress.cc:206: Failure
109: Expected: (static_cast<unsigned int>(pubDiff.nsec)) < ((g_localPublishMessageCount * nodes.size()) * 1600), actual: 55549858 vs 32000000
109: [1;32mMsg[0m Time to publish 20000 = 0 55549858
109: [1;32mMsg[0m Time to receive 40000000 = 26 810402208
109: [  FAILED  ] TransportStressTest.ManyNodes (39092 ms)
```

  • contact_sensor: ContactSensor.StackTestODE

content.raw:
That failure listed above wasn't repeatable. I've managed to create a repeatable failure, but it's not a SIGABRT; it's a gzserver hang.

Procedure:

1. `gzserver` in one terminal
2. `gzstats` in another terminal
2. `gzclient` in another terminal (optional)
3. make sure you have the bookshelf model in your .gazebo/models folder
4. run the following in another terminal; it just spawns and deletes models repeatedly with gzfactory
~~~
for i in `seq 1 10`; do \
  gzfactory spawn -f ~/.gazebo/models/bookshelf/model-1_3.sdf -m bookshelf_$i && \
  sleep 0.5 && \
  gzfactory delete -m bookshelf_$i && \
  sleep 0.5; done
~~~
After a couple iterations, it will hang, which can be verified by watching gzstats. I did `gdb gzserver` one time to see where it was hanging and got a backtrace, but I put it in #623 to reduce the verbosity of my comments here.
content.html:
That failure listed above wasn't repeatable. I've managed to create a repeatable failure, but it's not a SIGABRT; it's a gzserver hang.

Procedure:

  1. gzserver in one terminal
  2. gzstats in another terminal
  3. gzclient in another terminal (optional)
  4. make sure you have the bookshelf model in your .gazebo/models folder
  5. run the following in another terminal; it just spawns and deletes models repeatedly with gzfactory
for i in `seq 1 10`; do \
  gzfactory spawn -f ~/.gazebo/models/bookshelf/model-1_3.sdf -m bookshelf_$i && \
  sleep 0.5 && \
  gzfactory delete -m bookshelf_$i && \
  sleep 0.5; done

After a couple iterations, it will hang, which can be verified by watching gzstats. I did gdb gzserver one time to see where it was hanging and got a backtrace, but I put it in #623 to reduce the verbosity of my comments here.

content.raw:
I just tested this branch on Jenkins with the gazebo-any job. There are two test failures: TransportStressTest.ManyNodes and NonDefaultWorld.Load. http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64/59/

Here's the raw console output for TransportStressTest.ManyNodes:
~~~
101: [ RUN      ] TransportStressTest.ManyNodes
101: Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 1.6.1
101: Copyright (C) 2013 Open Source Robotics Foundation.
101: Released under the Apache 2 License.
101: http://gazebosim.org
...
101: [1;32mMsg[0m Waiting for master[1;32mMsg[0m Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
101: [1;32mMsg[0m Publicized address: 192.168.1.71
101: [1;31mError [RenderEngine.cc:608][0m Can't open display: 
101: [1;33mWarning [RenderEngine.cc:87][0m Unable to create X window. Rendering will be disabled
101: [1;36mDbg[0m ServerFixture load in 0.16 seconds, timeout after 60 seconds
101: [1;32mMsg[0m Publish complete
101: [1;33mWarning [Publisher.cc:127][0m Queue limit reached for topic /gazebo/default/diagnostics, deleting message. This warning is printed only once.
101: [1;33mWarning [Publisher.cc:127][0m Queue limit reached for topic /gazebo/default/physics/contacts, deleting message. This warning is printed only once.
101: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64/gazebo/test/regression/transport_stress.cc:196: Failure
101: Expected: (waitCount) < (50), actual: 50 vs 50
101: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64/gazebo/test/regression/transport_stress.cc:199: Failure
101: Value of: g_localPublishCount
101:   Actual: 3362832
101: Expected: g_totalExpectedMsgCount
101: Which is: 40000000
101: [1;32mMsg[0m Time to publish 20000 = 0 23202196
101: [1;32mMsg[0m Time to receive 3364223 = -8 -600090337
101: [  FAILED  ] TransportStressTest.ManyNodes (78543 ms)
~~~

The NonDefaultWorld.Load appears to fail when run on a machine with no display (I test this by ssh'ing to my own machine). The test loads much more quickly and fails before pose messages can be received by ServerFixture for the HasEntity call. Here's a patch that fixes the test for me without a display:
~~~
diff -r 237e08ff175c test/regression/nondefault_world.cc
--- a/test/regression/nondefault_world.cc	Tue Apr 09 16:18:31 2013 -0700
+++ b/test/regression/nondefault_world.cc	Tue Apr 09 18:00:33 2013 -0700
@@ -26,20 +26,12 @@
 TEST_F(NonDefaultWorld, Load)
 {
   math::Pose setPose, testPose;
-  Load("worlds/empty_different_name.world");
-  SetPause(false);
+  Load("worlds/empty_different_name.world", true);
+  physics::WorldPtr world = physics::get_world("not_the_default_world_name");
+  ASSERT_TRUE(world != NULL);
 
-  int i = 0;
-
-  // Wait for the entity to spawn
-  while (!HasEntity("ground_plane") && i < 10)
-  {
-    common::Time::MSleep(100);
-    ++i;
-  }
-
-  EXPECT_TRUE(HasEntity("ground_plane"));
-  EXPECT_LT(i, 10);
+  physics::ModelPtr model = world->GetModel("ground_plane");
+  ASSERT_TRUE(model);
 }
 
 int main(int argc, char **argv)
~~~
content.html:
I just tested this branch on Jenkins with the gazebo-any job. There are two test failures: TransportStressTest.ManyNodes and NonDefaultWorld.Load. http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64/59/

Here's the raw console output for TransportStressTest.ManyNodes:

101: [ RUN      ] TransportStressTest.ManyNodes
101: Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 1.6.1

...

101: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64/gazebo/test/regression/transport_stress.cc:196: Failure

101: [1;32mMsg[0m Time to receive 3364223 = -8 -600090337
101: [  FAILED  ] TransportStressTest.ManyNodes (78543 ms)

The NonDefaultWorld.Load appears to fail when run on a machine with no display (I test this by ssh'ing to my own machine). The test loads much more quickly and fails before pose messages can be received by ServerFixture for the HasEntity call. Here's a patch that fixes the test for me without a display:

diff -r 237e08ff175c test/regression/nondefault_world.cc
--- a/test/regression/nondefault_world.cc   Tue Apr 09 16:18:31 2013 -0700
+++ b/test/regression/nondefault_world.cc   Tue Apr 09 18:00:33 2013 -0700
@@ -26,20 +26,12 @@
 TEST_F(NonDefaultWorld, Load)
 {
   math::Pose setPose, testPose;
-  Load("worlds/empty_different_name.world");
-  SetPause(false);
+  Load("worlds/empty_different_name.world", true);
+  physics::WorldPtr world = physics::get_world("not_the_default_world_name");
+  ASSERT_TRUE(world != NULL);

-  int i = 0;
-
-  // Wait for the entity to spawn
-  while (!HasEntity("ground_plane") && i < 10)
-  {
-    common::Time::MSleep(100);
-    ++i;
-  }
-
-  EXPECT_TRUE(HasEntity("ground_plane"));
-  EXPECT_LT(i, 10);
+  physics::ModelPtr model = world->GetModel("ground_plane");
+  ASSERT_TRUE(model);
 }

 int main(int argc, char **argv)

content.raw:
I noted in the discussion of issue #623 that I was observing SIGABRT's when deleting models when I reduced the sleep time for the ConnectionManager (see #623 for backtraces). In some preliminary testing of this branch, I've managed to catch another one, though I had to insert and delete about 20 models before observing it, rather than 4-5. This time it's at Node::ProcessIncoming
~~~
gzserver: /usr/include/boost/thread/pthread/pthread_mutex_scoped_lock.hpp:26: boost::pthread::pthread_mutex_scoped_lock::pthread_mutex_scoped_lock(pthread_mutex_t*): Assertion `!pthread_mutex_lock(m)' failed.
